title: 114_hr5480
content: The Act is titled the "Boosting Equity for the American Middle Class Act of 2016" or the "BEAM Act of 2016." It introduces a refundable credit for early principal payments on certain home mortgages under a new section 36C of the Internal Revenue Code. The "BEAM Act of 2016" introduces a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments made by individuals, equal to 50% of the payments, with an annual limit of $500. There is a lifetime limitation of 10 years and a restriction based on modified adjusted gross income. The BEAM Act of 2016 offers a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments, capped at $500 annually. There is a lifetime limit of 10 years and a restriction based on modified adjusted gross income. The credit for excess home mortgage principal payments is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, with a minimum reduction of zero. The taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income determines the reduction of the credit for excess home mortgage principal payments, with a minimum reduction of zero. The term 'modified adjusted gross income' is defined as adjusted gross income increased by any amount excluded from gross income under specific sections. Excess home mortgage principal payments refer to the amount of principal paid by the taxpayer exceeding the qualified home mortgage indebtedness for a taxable year. The term 'excess home mortgage principal payments' refers to the amount of principal paid by the taxpayer exceeding the qualified home mortgage indebtedness for a taxable year. The term 'qualified home mortgage indebtedness' refers to acquisition indebtedness for a residence as defined in section 163(h)(3)(B). The term 'qualified home mortgage indebtedness' includes acquisition indebtedness for a primary residence that meets specific criteria. Acquisition indebtedness for a primary residence must be a traditional mortgage with a term of 15 to 30 years and equal payments. The term 'traditional mortgage' refers to an indebtedness with a term of 15 to 30 years, with equal payments made at regular intervals. The term 'traditional mortgage' refers to an indebtedness with equal payments made at regular intervals during the term. Rules related to joint returns require married individuals to file jointly to claim a credit. The credit under this section is only allowed for married individuals filing jointly. If the credit is claimed on a joint return, it is considered as allowed for both spouses. The credit under this section is allowed for joint returns, treating both spouses as having been allowed the credit for 10 or more preceding taxable years. The taxpayer is treated as having been allowed the credit for 10 or more preceding taxable years if both spouses have received such credits. Additionally, excess home mortgage principal payments received during the calendar year must be reported. The taxpayer must report excess home mortgage principal payments received during the calendar year. Amendments are made to sections 6211(b)(4)(A) and 1324(b)(2) of the Code to include section 36C. Amendments are made to sections 6211(b)(4)(A) and 1324(b)(2) of the Code to include section 36C. Conforming amendments are also made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments made to include section 36C in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Effective date for the amendments is for taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act.
